Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Interdisciplinary Program in Multi-scale Biological Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Rice University, located in Houston, TX, will support the training of ten students for ten weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. This REU site seeks to expose students to the excitement of biological research and the increasing contributions that different science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines are making towards a detailed understanding of biological systems. To achieve this, students will work in labs that draw from an array of approaches - from classical biochemical and genetic to non-trivial theoretical modeling that requires computation. The research areas include: (i) biomolecular structure, function, and evolution, (ii) naturally-occurring genetic networks, (iii) synthetic genetic and metabolic networks, and (iv) ecological networks. The participating faculty mentors come from a range of departments including Biosciences, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Chemistry, and Computer Science. In addition to research, students will participate in workshops that focus on ethics and responsible conduct of research, professional communication, career opportunities, and the graduate school application process. In addition to presenting their research at a capstone poster symposium, students will be provided a creative opportunity to develop innovative biotechnology proposal ideas by working in collaborative groups.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will be recruited nationwide, with an emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving institutions, including community colleges and four-year institutions. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine student career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available at http://ibb.rice.edu/Content.aspx?id=563, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Joff Silberg at joff@rice.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. George Bennett at gbennett@rice.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are multiple challenges associated with training the future generation of biological researchers in the tools that will be critical to solving problems in this field. Current strategies that simply focus on modifying undergraduate curriculum have been limited in the pace at which they achieve their goals. With this approach, students often do not choose the more quantitative tracks that become available within their biological major because their excitement was not stimulated before they declared that major. In addition, students that pursue such tracks often do not obtain enough depth in quantitative concepts to serve them well in their future careers. To overcome this challenge, a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites was coordinated at Rice University that provided research training for 10 students per summer, for 10 weeks during the summers of 2016-2019. This approach was used to provide students earlier exposure to the importance of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics in biological research. 

Students were recruited nationwide, with particular emphasis on students enrolled at proximal minority-serving two- and four-year institutions. Extensive efforts were made to recruit from two-year community college institutions, including proximal institutions such as Houston Community College and San Jacinto College, which have large enrollments (>100,000 students). These efforts resulted in a dramatic (10-fold) increase in applicants from these institutions compared with prior programs. Selection of students was done based on the faculty steering committee?s evaluation of each applicant?s transcript and recommendation letters. Rice?s Institute of Biosciences and Bioengineering (IBB) administered this NSF REU Program. Efforts were made to recruit from diverse groups. During the period of this award, more than half of the interns were from underrepresented groups, more than half of the interns were women, and more than half of the interns were enrolled at schools that lack research opportunities such as two-year institutions. Additionally, approximately half of the interns were first generation college students. 

This topical focus of this program was biological networks, complex interactions among biomolecules that give rise to the diverse biological phenotypes observed in nature. Students worked on research projects under faculty mentors that drew from a range of approaches (classical biochemical and genetic to non-trivial theoretical models that require computation) to study naturally-occurring genetic networks, artificial genetic and metabolic networks, and biomolecular structure, function, and evolution. Faculty from diverse departments served as mentors, including faculty within the Departments of Biosciences, Bioengineering, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Chemistry, Computer Science, Earth Sciences, and Environmental Engineering. Students were matched with faulty mentors who pursued similar undergraduate majors, which catalyzed discussions of the ways in which diverse majors can support cutting-edge biological research. Individual development plans were used to help students reflect on the activities needed to achieve their career goals

In this program, students conducted full-time lab research and participated in seminars and workshops with topics ranging from responsible conduct in research and professional communication skills to career opportunities and the graduate school application process. Additional activities included attendance of faculty presentations on bionetworks research, a tour of a Texas Medical Center research facility, and cohort building activities. Students were also provided a creative opportunity to develop innovative technological ideas in small groups, as well as a capstone research poster symposium. The group projects within this REU site provided a unique creative outlet for students, which they typically do not experience in standard research projects. By having the students work in small multidisciplinary groups, we fostered student-student interactions across disciplines and exposed students to the benefits and challenges required by today?s team approach to STEM projects.
